Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Simplified Pneumatic Otoscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project, if successful, is an improvement in diagnosis and treatment of middle ear infections, a disease that affects greater than 90% of the world's population. Middle ear infections are the leading cause of hearing loss in children and responsible for more surgeries than any other childhood disease. Correct diagnosis of fluid in the middle ear space is crucial to proper treatment to avoid extended hearing loss. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends pneumatic otoscopy as a key diagnostic for the identification of fluid in the middle ear, yet only 25% of physicians even attempt this exam because it is difficult to obtain a seal of the ear canal, which is a requirement for the technique. Over-prescription of antibiotics has become a significant problem, leading to antibiotic resistance and wasted resources. This project will prove the concept of a pneumatic otoscopy technique that does not require a seal of the ear canal, leading to a much simpler, yet equally effective exam. This will, in turn, lead to increased compliance with the academy-recommended guidelines and improved patient outcomes.

The proposed project will develop tools to improve the success rate of pneumatic otoscopy, enabling physicians to comply with the guidelines set forth by the American Academy of Pediatrics and to better diagnose and treat otitis media with effusion. In pneumatic otoscopy, a physician views the surface of the eardrum while changing the pressure in the ear canal to cause the eardrum to move. If the middle ear is filled with fluid, then the eardrum does not move appreciably. The proposed tools will leverage thermodynamic principles in novel ways to abolish the requirement of sealing the canal. They will be low-cost, enabling access to the technology even for the solo practitioner. The proposed project will (1) design and build prototypes of these tools, (2) characterize the tools on a lab bench, and (3) characterize the tools in a simulation model of the human ear. The project will culminate in data that teaches whether or not the proposed tools will suitably inform the physician about the presence of fluid in the ear.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated a potential solution to one of the biggest problems that physicians currently face when diagnosing ear infections. Currently diagnostic technologies used by physicians have poor diagnostic accuracy when trying to assess fluid in the middle ear during ear infections. Pneumatic otoscopy is the recommended method for detecting fluid in the ear. During pneumatic otoscopy, the physician inserts the speculum tip of an otoscope into the ear canal to observe and assess the eardrum. During otoscopy, if the eardrum is sufficiently translucent, there may be an opportunity to qualitatively visualize whether or not an effusion (fluid) is present in the underlying middle ear. The pneumatic aspect of the exam is used to confirm fluid via manual movement of the eardrum using an insufflation bulb, which requires a seal of the ear canal with the otoscope speculum; however, this seal is difficult to obtain and maintain, and consequently, very few physicians perform the exam. Current disposable speculum tips are made from hard plastic and their design does not seal the ear canal reliably well, and without a seal of the ear canal, the pneumatic otoscopy exam is not useful.

The intellectual merit of this project was based on the thermodynamic science, engineering, and technology we developed for a simplified pneumatic otoscopy exam. Through the support of this project, we have developed a new way to examine the mobility of the eardrum without requiring a seal of the canal. The promising results of this project are important to and align well with our company vision of enabling better ear disease diagnosis and management outcomes by developing superior tools for the medical professionals who manage these patients. This project proved the concept of simplified pneumatic otoscopy, resulting in multiple product opportunities. We envision a suite of three products that could each stand alone, but when combined result in an optimized and superior solution.

Disposable speculum tips were designed to deliver a controlled puff of air that can gently move the eardrum, in contrast to the sealed-canal volume expansion method used in current pneumatic exams. The air puff rings delivered from these speculum tips have shown great promise to be an easier, reliable method for moving the eardrum. An automated stimulus generator and preliminary video analysis algorithms were also developed and prototyped to support the novel speculum tips. The automated stimulus generator produces more repeatable, controlled puffs of air over that delivered with an insufflation bulb. And the video analysis algorithms were developed to automatically measure the deflection of the eardrum, and thereby improve exam accuracy and repeatability independent of user experience level.

The broader impact of this project is significant for all who suffer from middle ear disease. Ear infections are the leading cause of hearing loss and most common reason for surgery in children, affecting 80% of children before the age of three. In the U.S., they are responsible for 30 million annual visits to physicians and represent a nearly $10 billion economic burden. Our technology will provide physicians with a better tool and new quantitative and diagnostic information to better evaluate middle ear health and make appropriate treatment decisions for better clinical outcomes due to better management of antibiotics and more timely referral to a specialist.

Additionally, we were able to participate in a complementary broader community program: the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign Engineering Open House. This STEM education event is designed to encourage K-12 interest in STEM topics by showcasing projects and STEM-related activities in an “open house” format, inviting the local community of ~150,000 to join in the exciting science happening in the Urbana-Champaign area.


Last Modified: 09/16/2016
Modified by: Ryan L Shelton
